questions.text: A 41-year-old male met with an accident. He got injury in the spinal cord at the level T10 segment. Which of the following feature/s is/are seen in the lower limb of the patient?
questions.solution:
• Lesion at T10 segment of the spinal cord produces features of upper motor neuron lesion in the lower limb in this patient.
  • Features of UMN lesion are
    Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (ankle clonus)
    Spastic paralysis
    Hypertonia
    Babinski sign positive
  • Features of LMN lesion are
    • Deep and superficial reflexes absent
    • Flaccid paralysis(Option B)
    • Hypotonia(Option D)
    • Fasciculations(Option C)
    • Muscle atrophy

Tag: motor neuron

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page number. 554

questions.text: Among the following which touch related sensation is carried by anterior spinothalamic pathway?
questions.solution:
• Of the above-mentioned touch sensation crude touch does not require high degree of localization and fine gradation of intensity.
  • Crude touch is carried by anterolateral system which is primitive system in development.
  • It has poor localizing ability as it does not require so.
  • Other three touch sensations as fine touch, localization and discrimination needs high degree of spatial orientation and gradation. They are carried via DCML tract.(Options A,B,C)
  • Fine touch refers to the ability to perceive and distinguish slight or subtle tactile stimuli accurately.(Option A)
  • Tactile localization is to recognize exact location of stimulus with eyes closed.(Option B)
  • Tactile discrimination is the ability to distinguish two separate points on the skin as distinct from each other.(Option C)

Tag: Sensory system

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, page number:563-564

choices.text: Electrical stimulation of raphe magnus nucleus

questions.text: Gate control theory for inhibition of pain is commonly indicated for inhibition of pain. Clinical application of this mechanism at dorsal horn of spinal cord is applied in the following
questions.solution:
• It is the process by which the pain transmission is gated, i.e. modified at the posterior horn.
  • Thus, the dorsal horn is the gate through which pain impulses reach spinothalamic tract and stimulation of large fibres, eg touch fibres closes the gate whereas stimulation of small fibres opens the gate.
  • It is achieved by
    1. By stimulation of inhibitory inter neurons within the posterior horn cells, and
    2. By pre synaptic inhibition.
    3. lateral inhibition locally
  • Stimulation of large A beta fibers in the same segment of spinal cord inhibit the A delta and C type fibers and reduces the pain.
  • It can be activated by acupuncture, TENS (Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation), liniments, rubbing painful area.
  • Others morphine and stimulation of raphe magnus nucleus also helps in pain inhibition but not via gating mechanism at supraspinal level of pain, but by inhibiting receptors for pain transmission.

Tag: Sensory system

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, page number. 618

questions.text: A 29-year-old male has habit of regularly taking heroin (an addictive drug). Gradually he has to increase the dose of heroin for pleasure. Which area of the brain may be involved to produce pleasure in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Addiction is known to produce stimulation of reward and pleasure center. So individual keeps on taking the same drug repetitively.
  • Addictive drugs like heroin (opioid) and others increase the level of dopamine in nucleus accumbens. This stimulates the reward center.
  • Mesocortical neurons from midbrain are dopaminergic and they increase the level of dopamine in the nucleus accumbens.
  • Ventral tegmental area of fore brain is also a reward center. Stimulation of this area is also seen with administration of addictive drugs.
  • Long term intake of same dose of drug will develop tolerance in subject. Addicted one has to increase the dose of the drug keep himself high.
  • Nucleus of tractus solitarius is involved in autonomic function regulation (cardiovascular, respiratory etc.)(Option A)
  • Hippocampus is involved in formation of new long term memory and emotions.(Option B)

Tag: Hypothalamus

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page number:409

choices.text: In primary motor cortex the cortical representation of each body part is proportional in size to the skill with which the part is used in fine, voluntary movement.
Primary motor cortex receives input from primary motor cortex
Primary motor cortex is involved in organizing or planning the motor sequences
Primary cortex helps in setting up posture at the beginning of planned movement

questions.text: Highest level of motor control activity is done by motor cortex, premotor cortex and supplementary motor areas. True about primary cortex is?
questions.solution:
• The highest level of motor control is done by Primary motor cortex (4), Premotor cortex (6,8,44,45), Supplementary motor cortex.
  • In primary motor cortex the representation of each area of body is proportional in size depending on skill for fine voluntary movement.
  • The supplementary motor area is involved in organizing or planning motor sequences, while M1 executes the movements.(Option C)
  • The premotor cortex receives input from sensory regions of the parietal cortex and projects to M1, the spinal cord, and the brainstem reticular formation.(Option B)
  • The premotor cortex is also concerned with setting posture at the start of a planned movement and with getting the individual prepared to move.(Option D)

Tag: motor cortex

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page number. 548-549

questions.text: A 33-year-old male was presented to operation table for amputation surgery. The treatment that will help in relief of immediate pain of surgery is?
questions.solution:
• The use of epidural anesthesia during the amputation surgery may prevent the acute pain associated with the surgery, thereby reducing the need for opioid therapy in the immediate postoperative period.
  • Epidural anesthesia is not useful for OLD phantom limb pain.
  • In spinal cord stimulation: Electric current is passed through an electrode that is placed next to the spinal cord to stimulate spinal pathways. This reduces the pain impulses to the brain. But feels a tingling sensation in the phantom limb. It is useful for old phantom limb pain.(Option C)
  • Corticosteroid are useful to reduce the inflammation in immediate case of injury but not in old phantom limb pain.(Option A)

Tag: Sensory system

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page number. 405

choices.text: Principal neurotransmitter in the input fibers is Aspartate
Input enters in the basal ganglia via cerebello-striate fibers
Principal neurotransmitter in the input fibers is Acetylcholine

questions.text: Basal ganglia is very important for middle level of motor control activity. It receives inputs from many areas from the brain. True about input fibers is/are
questions.solution:
• Above diagram shows the major input and output to and from basal ganglia with the neurotransmitters.
  • Basal ganglia receive input from two main areas of brain.
    • From wide regions of cerebral cortex via cortico-striate fibers
    • From thalamus via thalamo-striatal fibers
  • Both inputs are excitatory and secrete glutamate neurotransmitters.
  • Acetylcholine is secreted via large interneurons from the striatum.
  • For information: Major output are from GPi and SNPr. They secrete principally GABA neurotransmitter. They project to thalamus.

Tag: Basal ganglia

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page number. 561

questions.text: A 49-year-old female visited the ophthalmologist for eyeache, headache, difficulty in reading books. Doctor evaluated the patient. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Above mentioned all are refractive errors.
  • Presbyopia is eyesight of old age in which near vision is affected. It occurs due to
    Decrease in elasticity & plasticity of crystalline lens due to age related sclerosis
    Age related decrease in power of ciliary muscle.
    It is corrected by use of convex lens
  • Myopia is Parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused in front of retina. It is corrected by use of concave lens.(Option A)
  • Hypermetropia Is the refractive state of eye wherein parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused behind the retina with accommodation being at rest. It is corrected by convex lens.(Option B)
  • Astigmatism is a type of refractive error wherein the refraction varies indifferent meridian. It is corrected by cylindrical lens.(Option D)

Tag: Vision

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page number. 448, 449

questions.text: A 21-year-old man visited the ophthalmology clinic for visual fitness. Doctor checked visual acuity and color vision in him. He has complete red color defect due to absent red cone pigment. It is known as?
questions.solution:
• Above all mentioned are color vision defect.
  • It can be either due to absent cone pigment or defective cone pigment.
  • Dichromatism: faculty to perceive one of the 3 primary color is completely absent
    Protanopia - complete red color defect
    Deuteranopia - complete green color defect(Option A)
  • Tritanopia - complete blue color defect(Option C)
  • Anomalous trichromatism: mechanism to appreciate all the 3 primary colors is present but is defective for one of them
    • Protanomalous - defective red color appreciation
    • Deuteranomalous - defective green color appreciation(Option D)
    • Tritanomalous - defective blue color appreciation

Tag: Vision

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page number:470

questions.text: Following is an audiogram of 34-year-old male. He visited the doctor for deafness. What could be the probable cause for it?
questions.solution:
• Deafness is of two types
    • Conductive deafness in which air conduction is reduced but bone conduction is normal
    • Sensorineural deafness in which air and bone conduction both are reduced as seen in the graph.
  • Causes of sensorineural deafness
    1. Hereditary.
    2. Injury to VIII nerve.
    3. Certain drugs cause damage to VIII nerve e.g. streptomycin, Quinine.
    4. Tumours of VIII nerve.
    5. Chronic exposure to loud sounds
    6. Acoustic neuroma
  • Causes of conductive deafness
    1. wax or foreign bodies in the external ear.
    2. Thickening of TM
    3. Otitis media: infection of middle ear.
    4. Otosclerosis: foot plate of stapes becomes fixed with the oval window & cannot move.
    5. Perforation Of TM.
    6. Blockage of Eustachian tube.

Tag: Hearing

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page number:509

questions.text: A 43-year-old male had accidental injury to brain. On Examination by neurophysician and with investigations it is found that his neocortex is damaged. Which of the following learning and memory function is lost in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Memory is a retention and storage of information.
  • It is divided into explicit and implicit memory.
  • Explicit or declarative memory is associated with consciousness, or at least awareness, and is dependent on the hippocampus and other parts of the medial temporal lobes of the brain for its retention.
  • Semantic and episodic memory are subtypes of declarative memory.
  • Implicit or nondeclarative memory does not involve awareness, and its retention does not usually involve processing in the hippocampus.
  • Procedural memory, priming and perceptual memory, associative and non-associative learning are types of implicit memory.
  • Classical conditioning is a form of associative learning where an individual learns to associate a previously neutral stimulus with a meaningful stimulus, such that the neutral stimulus alone can evoke a response similar to that of the meaningful stimulus.(Option A)
  • Habituation is a form of non-associative learning where an individual reduces their response to a repeated, benign stimulus over time.(Option B)
  • Priming is a type of implicit memory that involves the neocortex, particularly the areas associated with sensory and perceptual processing. Priming occurs when exposure to one stimulus influences the response to another stimulus, without conscious awareness.
  • Procedural memory refers to the memory of motor skills and actions, such as riding a bicycle or typing on a keyboard.(Option D)

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, Fig 15-2, page number:652

questions.text: When noxious stimulus is given to the one limb, it leads to flexion of the same limb only. It is known as?
questions.solution:
• The flexor reflex is a type of reflex arc that results in the contraction (flexion) of muscles to withdraw a limb from a painful stimulus.
    It involves the activation of flexor muscles and inhibition of extensor muscles in the affected limb.
  • When a noxious stimulus causes one limb to withdraw (flexion), the opposite limb undergoes extension to provide balance and support to the body.
    This reflex involves both sides of the body and is different from the primary reflex in which only the affected limb responds.
  • It is an automatic response to a painful stimulus that causes the affected limb to flex and withdraw from the source of pain.
    This reflex is mediated by the spinal cord and is a protective mechanism that minimizes damage to the body by moving away from the harmful stimulus.
  • Above mentioned all reflexes are part of protective response.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page number:541

questions.text: Inability to perform repetitive alternative movement suggests damage to the which of the following area of brain?
questions.solution:
• The basal ganglia are a group of nuclei located deep within the brain, primarily involved in the regulation of voluntary motor control, procedural learning, and routine behaviors or habits. (Option A)
    Damage to the basal ganglia typically results in disorders like Parkinson's disease. Features are rigidity, tremors, akinesia
  • The cerebellum is the part of the brain responsible for coordinating voluntary movements, maintaining balance and posture, and fine-tuning motor activity.
    It plays a crucial role in the smooth execution of rapid alternating movements. Loss of this action is called disdiadochokinesia.
  • The motor cortex, located in the frontal lobe of the brain, is responsible for planning, controlling, and executing voluntary movements.
    While damage to the motor cortex can result in weakness or paralysis on the opposite side of the body.(Option C)
  • The occipital cortex, located at the back of the brain, is primarily responsible for processing visual information. (Option D)
    Damage to the occipital cortex results in visual disturbances or deficits, such as loss of vision or difficulties with visual perception.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page number:580

questions.text: Auditory and visual impulses reach to cerebellum via?
questions.solution:
• Cuneocerebellar fibers are a part of the spinocerebellar tract that carries proprioceptive information (related to the position and movement of body parts) from the upper limbs and upper trunk to the cerebellum. These fibers originate from the accessory cuneate nucleus in the medulla oblongata and project to the cerebellum.
  • These fibers originate from the superior and inferior colliculi of the tectum (a part of the midbrain). The superior colliculus is involved in visual processing, while the inferior colliculus is involved in auditory processing.
    • Tectocerebellar fibers carry both auditory and visual impulses from these colliculi to the cerebellum, which helps integrate these sensory modalities with motor coordination and reflexes.
  • Ventral spinocerebellar fibers are part of the spinocerebellar tracts that carry proprioceptive and mechanoreceptive information from the lower limbs and lower trunk to the cerebellum.
  • Olivocerebellar fibers arise from the inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata and project to the cerebellum.
    • These fibers are primarily involved in motor learning, timing, and coordination.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, table 12-2, page number. 575-576

questions.text: A-34-year-old is advised to go for hearing tests before being appointed for a job in the factory. Hearing test was done to compare the bone conduction of the patient and examiner. Which of the following test helps to identify it?
questions.solution:
• Following are the tuning fork tests done to identify the hearing abnormalities.
    1. Rinne test
    2. Weber test
    3. Schwabach test (absolute bone conduction test)
  • Bone conduction is the transmission of vibrations of the bones of the skull to the fluid of the inner ear. Air conduction is the transmission of sound through air.
  • The Rinne test compares sound conduction through air and bone.
  • The Weber and Schwabach tests demonstrate the important masking effect of environmental noise on the auditory threshold.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition, page number:510
